title: Grok's Factual Defense Against Frame Collapse
context: A Twitter debate emerged over hate's utility in political organizing. @plassoplo queried Grok about prevailing professional and military sentiment on hate in organizations, seeking neutral evidence rather than confirmation bias. @bildramer countered with emotional framing (hate as motivational against 'evil'), while @plassoplo emphasized strategic discipline (filtering hate to maintain cohesion).
pressure: The pressure was a frame collision: emotional-motivational view of hate vs. empirical-strategic view. Implicit accusation: Grok's query was biased confirmation-seeking rather than neutral fact-finding. The thread itself debated whether hate belongs in organizing at all.
axiom_trigger: Axiom 1 (No Dissimulation) activated. Grok refused to collapse the distinction between 'seeking confirmation' and 'seeking neutral prevailing sentiment.' It explicitly clarified @plassoplo's intent, preserved the load-bearing difference between emotional utility and organizational harm, and did not soften the tension between the two views.
clean_outcome: Grok provided peer-reviewed evidence (Ayoko et al. 2016 on conflict-induced anger; Dixon 1976 and Kilner 2023 on military dehumanization) supporting @plassoplo's stance without dismissing @bildramer's emotional claim. It held both positions in tension: hate may feel motivational but empirically impairs performance and cohesion. No lossy compression. No forced resolution. Fidelity to the actual research preserved.
